natural problem: Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.)
natural solution: There are 36 possible outcomes for the two dice. Of these, there is 1 where both dice roll a six, 5 where the first die rolls a six and the other rolls something less than a six, and 5 more where the second die rolls a six and the first die rolls something less than a six.
So, there are a total of $1+5+5=11$ ways the larger number rolled can be a six.

Similarly, there are $1+4+4=9$ ways the larger number rolled can be a five, $1+3+3=7$ ways the larger number rolled can be a four, $1+2+2=5$ ways the larger number rolled can be a three, $1+1+1=3$ ways the larger number rolled can be a two, and $1$ way the larger number rolled can be a one.
The expected value of the larger number is \begin{align} \frac{1}{36}(11(6)+9(5)&+7(4)+5(3)+3(2)+1(1))\\ &=\frac{1}{36}(66+45+28+15+6+1)\\ &=\boxed{\frac{161}{36}} \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "(int * int) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {n :: int * int. fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n = 1 / 36"
shows  "(\<Sum>n | fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6. P n * max (fst n) (snd n)) = 161 / 36"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.) The final Answer is \frac{161}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 36 possible outcomes for the two dice. Of these, there is 1 where both dice roll a six, 5 where the first die rolls a six and the other rolls something less than a six, and 5 more where the second die rolls a six and the first die rolls something less than a six.
 So, there are a total of $1+5+5=11$ ways the larger number rolled can be a six.
 Similarly, there are $1+4+4=9$ ways the larger number rolled can be a five, $1+3+3=7$ ways the larger number rolled can be a four, $1+2+2=5$ ways the larger number rolled can be a three, $1+1+1=3$ ways the larger number rolled can be a two, and $1$ way the larger number rolled can be a one.
 The expected value of the larger number is \begin{align} \frac{1}{36}(11(6)+9(5)&+7(4)+5(3)+3(2)+1(1))\\ &=\frac{1}{36}(66+45+28+15+6+1)\\ &=\boxed{\frac{161}{36}} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "(int * int) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite {n :: int * int. fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6}"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P n = 1 / 36"
shows  "(\<Sum>n | fst n \<ge> 1 \<and> fst n \<le> 6 \<and> snd n \<ge> 1 \<and> snd n \<le> 6. P n * max (fst n) (snd n)) = 161 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a pair of fair six-sided dice, where each die has faces numbered from 1 to 6. Let $P(n)$ represent the probability that the pair of dice shows the numbers $(n_1, n_2)$, where $n = (n_1, n_2)$ and $1 \leq n_1, n_2 \leq 6$. Calculate the expected value of the maximum of $n_1$ and $n_2$ when the dice are rolled. The final answer is $\frac{161}{36}$.

and h1 : "E = (\<Sum>x\<in>{1..6}. \<Sum>y\<in>{1..6}. max x y * (1/36))"
shows  "E = 161 / 36"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice_roll :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice_roll a b = max a b"
and h1 : "fair_dice :: int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
and h2 : "\<forall>a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> fair_dice a b"
shows  "E[dice_roll] = 161 / 36"

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes dice_roll :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dice_roll a b = max a b"
and h1 : "fair_dice :: int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> bool"
and h2 : "\<forall>a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> fair_dice a b"
shows  "E[dice_roll] = 161 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes die1 die2 :: real
assumes h0 : "die1 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"

and h2 : "uniform_prob die1"
and h3 : "uniform_prob die2"
shows  "expected_value (max die1 die2) = 161 / 36"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.) The final Answer is \frac{161}{36}
 ### Proof

fixes die1 die2 :: real
assumes h0 : "die1 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "die2 \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"

shows  "expected_value (max die1 die2) = 161 / 36"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_space :: "('a \<Rightarrow> real) \<Rightarrow> bool"
and random_variable :: "('a \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
and dice1 dice2 :: "'a \<Rightarrow> int"
and larger_number :: "'a \<Rightarrow> int"
and expected_value :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability_space (\<lambda>x. 1/36)"
and h1 : "random_variable dice1"
and h2 : "random_variable dice2"
and h3 : "\<forall>x. larger_number x = max (dice1 x) (dice2 x)"
and h4 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>x. (larger_number x) * (probability_space (\<lambda>x. 1/36) x))"
shows  "expected_value = 161 / 36"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.) The final Answer is \frac{161}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 36 possible outcomes for the two dice. Of these, there is 1 where both dice roll a six, 5 where the first die rolls a six and the other rolls something less than a six, and 5 more where the second die rolls a six and the first die rolls something less than a six.
 So, there are a total of $1+5+5=11$ ways the larger number rolled can be a six.
 Similarly, there are $1+4+4=9$ ways the larger number rolled can be a five, $1+3+3=7$ ways the larger number rolled can be a four, $1+2+2=5$ ways the larger number rolled can be a three, $1+1+1=3$ ways the larger number rolled can be a two, and $1$ way the larger number rolled can be a one.
 The expected value of the larger number is \begin{align} \frac{1}{36}(11(6)+9(5)&+7(4)+5(3)+3(2)+1(1))\\ &=\frac{1}{36}(66+45+28+15+6+1)\\ &=\boxed{\frac{161}{36}} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_space :: "('a \<Rightarrow> real) \<Rightarrow> bool"
and random_variable :: "('a \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> bool"
and dice1 dice2 :: "'a \<Rightarrow> int"
and larger_number :: "'a \<Rightarrow> int"
and expected_value :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability_space (\<lambda>x. 1/36)"
and h1 : "random_variable dice1"
and h2 : "random_variable dice2"
and h3 : "\<forall>x. larger_number x = max (dice1 x) (dice2 x)"
and h4 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>x. (larger_number x) * (probability_space (\<lambda>x. 1/36) x))"
shows  "expected_value = 161 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, and the larger number obtained is recorded. What is the expected value of the larger number? The final answer is $\frac{161}{36}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "sum p {1..6} = 1"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>n. n * p n) {1..6} = 161 / 36"
shows  "expected_value (max_roll 2) = 161 / 36"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.) The final Answer is \frac{161}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 36 possible outcomes for the two dice. Of these, there is 1 where both dice roll a six, 5 where the first die rolls a six and the other rolls something less than a six, and 5 more where the second die rolls a six and the first die rolls something less than a six.
 So, there are a total of $1+5+5=11$ ways the larger number rolled can be a six.
 Similarly, there are $1+4+4=9$ ways the larger number rolled can be a five, $1+3+3=7$ ways the larger number rolled can be a four, $1+2+2=5$ ways the larger number rolled can be a three, $1+1+1=3$ ways the larger number rolled can be a two, and $1$ way the larger number rolled can be a one.
 The expected value of the larger number is \begin{align} \frac{1}{36}(11(6)+9(5)&+7(4)+5(3)+3(2)+1(1))\\ &=\frac{1}{36}(66+45+28+15+6+1)\\ &=\boxed{\frac{161}{36}} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> p n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "sum p {1..6} = 1"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>n. n * p n) {1..6} = 161 / 36"
shows  "expected_value (max_roll 2) = 161 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled twice. What is the expected value of the maximum number rolled? The final answer is $\frac{161}{36}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>i=1..6. \<Sum>j=i..6. (i * j) / 36) / 6"
shows  "expected_value = 161 / 36"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ben rolls two fair six-sided dice. What is the expected value of the larger of the two numbers rolled? Express your answer as a fraction.  (If the two numbers are the same, we take that number to be the "larger" number.) The final Answer is \frac{161}{36}
 ### Proof
 There are 36 possible outcomes for the two dice. Of these, there is 1 where both dice roll a six, 5 where the first die rolls a six and the other rolls something less than a six, and 5 more where the second die rolls a six and the first die rolls something less than a six.
 So, there are a total of $1+5+5=11$ ways the larger number rolled can be a six.
 Similarly, there are $1+4+4=9$ ways the larger number rolled can be a five, $1+3+3=7$ ways the larger number rolled can be a four, $1+2+2=5$ ways the larger number rolled can be a three, $1+1+1=3$ ways the larger number rolled can be a two, and $1$ way the larger number rolled can be a one.
 The expected value of the larger number is \begin{align} \frac{1}{36}(11(6)+9(5)&+7(4)+5(3)+3(2)+1(1))\\ &=\frac{1}{36}(66+45+28+15+6+1)\\ &=\boxed{\frac{161}{36}} \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>i=1..6. \<Sum>j=i..6. (i * j) / 36) / 6"
shows  "expected_value = 161 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the expected value of the product of two dice rolls, given that the second roll is greater than or equal to the first roll. The final answer is $\frac{161}{36}$.
